Pros: Working from home. Big knowledge base.
Cons: Grueling process to be even considered for a promotion

Review Title: A Candid Look at Tata Consultancy Services for Business Analysts
Pros:
Professional Development Opportunities: TCS offers various training programs and resources for skill enhancement, providing avenues for professional growth and development for business analysts.

Diverse Project Exposure: Business analysts at TCS have the opportunity to work on a variety of projects spanning different industries and domains, allowing for a broadening of skills and knowledge.

Emphasis on Work-Life Balance: TCS promotes work-life balance through flexible work arrangements and wellness initiatives, demonstrating a commitment to supporting employees' overall well-being.
Cons:
Communication Challenges: There are instances where communication breakdowns have led to misunderstandings and delays in project timelines, highlighting the need for clearer communication channels within the organization.

Complexity of Projects: Some projects at TCS have been overly complex, requiring extensive problem-solving skills from business analysts. While this offers learning opportunities, it can also be overwhelming at times.

Workload Management: Despite efforts to promote work-life balance, there are occasions when project demands encroach upon this balance, necessitating careful time management and boundary-setting by employees.

Pros: There are a lot of learning platforms, but I bet you won't get time to use them. TCS, you shattered me into pieces. It took time, but I've gathered myself, and I'm in the process of repairing the damage you caused.
Cons:
A freshman who is hired in the US basically never gets any mentorships.
Most managers are busy with their tasks, and they have prejudice and jealousy toward freshmen who are immigrant Indians who are in permanent residence in the US. It might be because they had a hard way to get to the USA and still struggling because of visa issues.

Pros: Okay company, as long as you're not on the bench.
Cons:
Urgent Update: TCS is currently undergoing significant restructuring, which unfortunately includes massive layoffs in 2024. This is a stark reminder of the volatile nature of the IT industry and the unpredictable challenges we all face. It's my duty to share this news with the TCS community, not only to keep you informed but also to shed light on the harsh realities many are facing in today's economic climate. To those directly affected, I extend my deepest sympathies and support. I was laid off this week, without notice. 

Plan now for your next job... especially if you're on the bench and have been on the bench for longer than 2 weeks. Everyone on the bench is at risk!

Pros: They do take care of their employees in their own way. During COVID they were very understanding about it and didn't even make you use sick time or PTO. They gave me a severance package I didn't know I would get and had me "on the bench" for two months WITH PAY before letting me go.
Cons:
Management is all or nearly all Indian, and you don't get opportunities to move up very far if you're not.
They made us all take a class on how to deal with the Indian culture when we started. I'm sorry, but you are coming to America to do business, you should be working within OUR culture. I'm not going to go to India and demand American rights.
I noticed that the treated women and LGBTQ folks less seriously, either not promoting when they should, or outright firing for no reason.
The management are "yes men" to their clients, regardless as to whether the ask is in the scope of the contract or even achievable.
The amount of pointless corporate training is laughable, and some of it isn't even relevant to US personnel. Also, sometimes random classes are suddenly "mandatory" because some upper management has a goal to increase the group's training level. Pointless.

Review Title: Difficult Culture Shock with foreign business mentality. They don't work like other companies.
Pros:
Getting past the language/communication barriers, they are a great supportive group to engage with. They have great resources within to get anything done for a project. You will notice a network of employees to help and get solutions.
IF you do not act like a pompous/arrogant American and actually try to befriend your new Eastern co-workers, You can really have a team to support you to navigate both companies.
Cons:
You will be an outcast when you realize how differently they do business. They are not aggressive with the client and if the client perceives that, the client ends up steering the project. You will have two employers; the client and TCS. You will have cultural engagement put upon you and it will be distracting from your immediate duties. If a choice between you or the client, they will go with keeping you quiet and acting like nothing is wrong with management. You are expendable.
Any processes complete, require a screenshot to prove it.

Pros:
Many projects
Good work life balance
Cons:
No innovation
Less pay
Good for freshers only

Pros: Good salary for the work done
Cons: Literally everything else. Don’t do it.

Review Title: Find the nearest exit and leave
Pros: Good Exposure as they will present you as a senior associate in front of clients
Cons: Experienced Poor Work life Balance

Pros: Great job security, various type of projects… THATS IT!
Cons:
Slow growth, Slow raise… The company is nice and values its employees alot, but if you are looking to climb the corporate ladder then look somewhere else. 
Benefits are not that great.
If you miss a day to log in your hours then it will automatically add your vacation leave, you have to manually go and decline it. I have lost many vacation days like this. 
Performance band is a joke! Favoritism is what gets you noticed and a good band at the end of the year. If you do your work you will get a C band, the ones who are favored and who barely do any work get a better performance band.

Review Title: Terrible work culture and little to no structure/communication
Pros: No pros to working here. Not a company I'd recommend where you'd want to feel respected and where you can grow,
Cons: They don't respect your boundaries as the work culture is a lot different in India. Lack of respect and communication when it comes to feedback or constructive criticism. They inundate you with hours of training and take up all of your bandwidth with unnecessary trainings.

Pros: Quite accommodating work culture from personal/professional life stand point.
Cons:
The same accommodating culture kind of ruins the balance as the lines are always blur. 
The organization is so huge that it is very likely that your potential will go unnoticed if you don't find yourself in the right surroundings/eco system. 
Associates who chose to stay and continue to contribute are seriously underpaid.

Pros: nothing good can be said
Cons: they lay off employees, once their contract with end user ends, they don't even try to find another role, they did not pay my parental leave, before I was laid off

Pros: Some of the pros are that if you are lucky you can get experience with some great companies
Cons:
They are super unorganized
You never know what is going on
There is no communication whatsoever
I would not recommend them

Review Title: Avoid this place if you want respect and dignity
Pros: being employed and receiving a pay check. The best part about this job is the fact that you are assigned to a client and work with them on a daily basis, so you don't have to deal with internal TCS as much.
Cons: Where to begin? as an American I am shocked at how the Indian work culture is; basically there's no respect, you are just a number. - HR doesn't help at all.. in fact they act against you - The internal system used by all employees is a massive joke (ultimatix) and everytime I open it I feel my blood pressure rise due to how badly designed it is. - There's no communication, other than the tons of daily spam you receive which makes things even more confusing. - If you are released from a project, don't expect any help in replacing you.. you have to actively look and beg other projects to take you (what is the job of a director here I wonder?) - they are focusing too much on this whole "diversity" trend which, frankly, does nothing.. it's simply a trend to look cool. - one of the worst on-boarding processes of any company I've seen in my life. There's much more, but you get the picture. My mind is boggled at how this company is still in business (at least here in the USA).

Pros:
Good work life balance

Cons:
Relative low salary
Most managers are crap/bad
Your enjoyment greatly depends on end client

Pros:
Initial learning program that provided some training in full stack development, will sometimes provide training before a project. Some projects allow you to work remotely.

Pay and benefits were ok, but not great, for a fresher
Cons: When you're on the bench, you can be fired at any time without warning, so there isn't really any job security. If you have to relocate for a project, they provide no assistance save for covering a few days in a hotel, and give you very little notice on when you need to move (I had 2 weeks notice) and communicate very poorly on important details like how long you are going to be there. Pretty much no opportunity for upward mobility because nobody at TCS really cares to know who you are and you hardly interact with them. I wouldn't stay here long.

ok to work and be paid

lofty management tier
resources come and go - limited group binding

Review Title: Operates like a firm from the 1990s
Pros:
Wide variety of clients and projects - if you are allowed to switch.
Lots of computer-based training available.
Hires MBAs from the lesser-known schools.
Cons:
A very "old school" company that suffers from endemic (unconscious?) biases throughout. Hard to navigate the company, build your own brand, find projects, find credentials, etc. Easy to replicate previous work without knowing it, no central knowledge repository, clunky internal systems.
Heavily biased towards Indian nationals on work visas - local hires seen as 2nd class employees and overlooked in favor of visa-carrying employees to keep them in country. As with all the Indian tech firms, "creative" use of the visa system (in any country) to their advantage to help price out local competition.
All senior leaders are Indian nationals, so career progression limited.
D&I really poor.
Benefits not very attractive and well behind the market leaders.

Pros: Work from home, nice coworkers (for the most part)

You are just a number in the account. Management does not know to treat senior employees with dignity and respect for the value that they add. Leadership keeps changing so does the vision and I'm surprised to the extent to which a person can be degraded just to please Client.

There is no empathy, dignity, or value for your contribution. They take advantage of resources that are dependent on the company to process their Visa further to settle in this country, I wonder how this type of company culture exists in this age, ancient school and micro-managers who keep changing all the time. HR complains are useless as they do not understand what is human rights. Worst experience in my career. Would never recommend it to a person who is looking for self-dignity and career growth.

Review Title: An Okay Employer, A Bit of a Mess
Pros: Great smart people; good ethical company; diversity of work and a very broad client base.
Cons: I was employed at TCS for 2.5 years as part of the CXT practice which was suddenly dissolved, its team members scattered to the wind. Being allocated to a project, I happened to survive, Before that, a large round of layoffs took out a good chunk of unallocated people from the rolls. The whole thing was handled quite sloppily, the communication from Corporate was terrible. The HR support in this company is practically non-existent. Lines of reporting are fuzzy. Professional development opportunities and career trajectory pathing opps are a joke. You are only valuable pretty much as a warm body allocated to a project and making the company money, otherwise you are vulnerable to the axe. If you are looking for a good place to work that invests in its employees, I might look elsewhere.

Review Title: Could have been worse, but could have been much better
Pros: Paid fairly well, and hired me right out of school with no experience. Position was fully remote.
Cons: Very disorganized. I was hired in a group of 250+ and we were all onboarded in a single video call. Afterwards, I believe I was misplaced after getting allocated to a project for around 2 months, as I received no communication from anyone for that period. Once I was actually on the project the training was basically nonexistant. The person before me more or less neglected to train me, then left after a month. After that I was stuck as the only onshore person supporting an application with an offshore team who effectively refused to teach me anything. After a year and a half of this, I was cut from the team to offshore more work, and after a month of being unallocated I was abruptly let go.

Pros: TCS treats the employees well when compared to other companies. They always provide opportunities after the current projects gets over.
Cons: Salary package is not in the market standard

Pros: Not that I can think of
Cons: Super bad management. No growth. Doesn't respect employees thought

Pros: Lots of incentive opportunities and access to continuous learning platforms to further your craft. As long as your performance review is good, you're guaranteed some sort of bonus - at least at entry level.
Cons:
Management can make things both very unpleasant and very confusing. There are a ton of profile and systems you have to do upkeep on that as a new employee I didn't know about until I was in trouble for not doing them. After initial training which is more of a "how to code." tutorial then training on the company, what you know is completely up to the first manager.

Also, how much you are involved with and enjoy your job is really dependent on the project. My first project I was treated like a temp worker and not even allowed to touch the code. I was strictly supposed to review logs and figure out where the problem was (not even solve it! Pass it on to someone else after that). There was quite little for me to do day-to-day and I became very discouraged. I would also be berated for not doing things that I was never told to do or HOW to do, to the point where another co-worker had to act as a buffer between me and management there.

My next assignment was much better in the beginning! I was treated like an employee who knew what they were doing and was given time to learn the code base and then was immediately expected to contribute. I loved that! Things started to go south later on because we started getting new team members and I was expected to do my job and also manage their jobs, even though I was just another developer. It was to the point I was working late because 80% of my day had been taken up with making sure they got their parts done as I was asked by my team lead.

In addition to that, this job has no employee protections against overtime or limits on working hours or days. If the client/project needs you after your 8 - 4 shift to come in 9pm to 12am you just HAVE to and no, you will not be paid for those hours. There was one point they wanted me to work 14 days straight, overtime on some of those days, with no breaks and no additional pay incentive. Yikes.

Pros: I have just started in TCS. It was a good experience with my green card process.
Cons: Looks like less increment year over year.
